member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.AutoScalingGroupRecommendation.Finding
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Finding.
The finding classification for the Auto Scaling group.
Findings for Auto Scaling groups include:
NotOptimized —An Auto Scaling group is considered not optimized when AWS Compute Optimizer identifies a recommendation that can provide better performance for your workload.
Optimized —An Auto Scaling group is considered optimized when Compute Optimizer determines that the group is correctly provisioned to run your workload based on the chosen instance type. For optimized resources, Compute Optimizer might recommend a new generation instance type.
The values that are returned might be NOT_OPTIMIZED or OPTIMIZED.

member.name: T:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.Filter
member.summary: Describes a filter that returns a more specific list of recommendations.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.Filter.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the filter.
Specify Finding to filter the results to a specific findings classification.
Specify RecommendationSourceType to filter the results to a specific resource type.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.Filter.Values
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Values.
The value of the filter.
If you specify the name parameter as Finding, and you're recommendations for an instance, then the valid values are Underprovisioned, Overprovisioned, NotOptimized, or Optimized.
If you specify the name parameter as Finding, and you're recommendations for an Auto Scaling group, then the valid values are Optimized, or NotOptimized.
If you specify the name parameter as RecommendationSourceType, then the valid values are EC2Instance, or AutoScalingGroup.

member.name: T:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.GetAutoScalingGroupRecommendationsRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetAutoScalingGroupRecommendations operation. Returns Auto Scaling group recommendations.
AWS Compute Optimizer currently generates recommendations for Auto Scaling groups that are configured to run instances of the M, C, R, T, and X instance families. The service does not generate recommendations for Auto Scaling groups that have a scaling policy attached to them, or that do not have the same values for desired, minimum, and maximum capacity. In order for Compute Optimizer to analyze your Auto Scaling groups, they must be of a fixed size. For more information, see the AWS Compute Optimizer User Guide.

member.summary:

Only one account ID can be specified per request.

member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetEnrollmentStatus operation. Returns the enrollment (opt in) status of an account to the AWS Compute Optimizer service.
If the account is a master account of an organization, this operation also confirms the enrollment status of member accounts within the organization.

member.summary: Describes an Amazon EC2 instance recommendation.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.InstanceRecommendation.AccountId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AccountId.
The AWS account ID of the instance recommendation.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.InstanceRecommendation.CurrentInstanceType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CurrentInstanceType.
The instance type of the current instance.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.InstanceRecommendation.Finding
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Finding.
The finding classification for the instance.
Findings for instances include:
Underprovisioned —An instance is considered under-provisioned when at least one specification of your instance, such as CPU, memory, or network, does not meet the performance requirements of your workload. Under-provisioned instances may lead to poor application performance.
Overprovisioned —An instance is considered over-provisioned when at least one specification of your instance, such as CPU, memory, or network, can be sized down while still meeting the performance requirements of your workload, and no specification is under-provisioned. Over-provisioned instances may lead to unnecessary infrastructure cost.
Optimized —An instance is considered optimized when all specifications of your instance, such as CPU, memory, and network, meet the performance requirements of your workload and is not over provisioned. An optimized instance runs your workloads with optimal performance and infrastructure cost. For optimized resources, AWS Compute Optimizer might recommend a new generation instance type.
The values that are returned might be UNDER_PROVISIONED, OVER_PROVISIONED, or OPTIMIZED.

The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the current instance.

member.name: T:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.ProjectedMetric
member.summary: Describes a projected utilization metric of a recommendation option, such as an Amazon EC2 instance.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.ProjectedMetric.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the projected utilization metric.
Memory metrics are only returned for resources that have the unified CloudWatch agent installed on them. For more information, see Enabling Memory Utilization with the CloudWatch Agent.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.ProjectedMetric.Timestamps
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Timestamps.
The time stamps of the projected utilization metric.

The values of the projected utilization metrics.

member.name: T:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.RecommendedOptionProjectedMetric
member.summary: Describes a projected utilization metric of a recommendation option.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.RecommendedOptionProjectedMetric.ProjectedMetrics
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ProjectedMetrics.
An array of objects that describe a projected utilization metric.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.RecommendedOptionProjectedMetric.Rank
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Rank.
The rank of the recommendation option projected metric.
The top recommendation option is ranked as 1.
The projected metric rank correlates to the recommendation option rank. For example, the projected metric ranked as 1 is related to the recommendation option that is also ranked as 1 in the same response.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.RecommendedOptionProjectedMetric.RecommendedInstanceType

member.name: T:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.UpdateEnrollmentStatusRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the UpdateEnrollmentStatus operation. Updates the enrollment (opt in) status of an account to the AWS Compute Optimizer service.
If the account is a master account of an organization, this operation can also enroll member accounts within the organization.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.UpdateEnrollmentStatusRequest.IncludeMemberAccounts
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property IncludeMemberAccounts.
Indicates whether to enroll member accounts within the organization, if the account is a master account of an organization.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.UpdateEnrollmentStatusRequest.Status
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Status.
The new enrollment status of the account.
Accepted options are Active or Inactive. You will get an error if Pending or Failed are specified.

member.name: T:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.UpdateEnrollmentStatusResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the UpdateEnrollmentStatus operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.UpdateEnrollmentStatusResponse.Status
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Status.
The enrollment status of the account.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.UpdateEnrollmentStatusResponse.StatusReason
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StatusReason.
The reason for the enrollment status of the account. For example, an account might show a status of Pending because member accounts of an organization require more time to be enrolled in the service.

member.summary:

The statistic of the utilization metric.

member.name: P:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.UtilizationMetric.Value
member.summary:

member.name: T:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.AmazonComputeOptimizerClient
member.summary:
Implementation for accessing ComputeOptimizer
AWS Compute Optimizer is a service that analyzes the configuration and utilization metrics of your AWS resources, such as EC2 instances and Auto Scaling groups. It reports whether your resources are optimal, and generates optimization recommendations to reduce the cost and improve the performance of your workloads. Compute Optimizer also provides recent utilization metric data, as well as projected utilization metric data for the recommendations, which you can use to evaluate which recommendation provides the best price-performance trade-off. The analysis of your usage patterns can help you decide when to move or resize your running resources, and still meet your performance and capacity requirements. For more information about Compute Optimizer, see the AWS Compute Optimizer User Guide.

member.name: M:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.AmazonComputeOptimizerClient.#ctor
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonComputeOptimizerClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.AmazonComputeOptimizerClient.GetAutoScalingGroupRecommendationsAsync(Amazon.ComputeOptimizer.Model.GetAutoScalingGroupRecommendationsRequest,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary:
Returns Auto Scaling group recommendations.
AWS Compute Optimizer currently generates recommendations for Auto Scaling groups that are configured to run instances of the M, C, R, T, and X instance families. The service does not generate recommendations for Auto Scaling groups that have a scaling policy attached to them, or that do not have the same values for desired, minimum, and maximum capacity. In order for Compute Optimizer to analyze your Auto Scaling groups, they must be of a fixed size. For more information, see the AWS Compute Optimizer User Guide.
